title: Will Marine Le Pen place either first or second in the 2022 French presidential election?
preds: 3rd place or worse finish seems impossible at this point: https://www.yahoo.com/news/france-nail-biting-election-macrons-091337207.html

- The National Front increased its votes over the last 3 elections constantly.
- The Ukraine war let Europeans think more about patriotism (which occurs more in right-wing parties)
- COVID demonstrations are getting exploited by right-wing parties
- However, drawing connections to the German elections in 2021, left-wing parties performed better than right-wing parties
"I don't like it but I guess things happen that way."
There was little doubt before; it's a certainty now.

Upward trend in polls as getting closer to election time, as well as a downward trend on the polling of competitors with a similar ideology that would suggest Le Pen will take on their share of the vote and likely be in the top 2.
Polls day have a bigger gap bw Le Pen and Melenchon than before
Don't want to be too overconfident here as Melenchon *is* within 2-5 points in some polls, however unlikely he actually wins
Sounds likely as she's been trending up.

Updating since recent polls find that right-wing voters may find Le Pen a suitable compromise candidate. She might even beat Macron due to the fracture left in France, but that's not the question here.
Updating given passage of time, Le Pen's competitors falling off, her polls are rising going into the election. Seems like she has it locked up for second place. 2% room for error for a surprise.
Marcon’s relationship with Putin will hurt him in the election

Will revisit as Macron can still damage chances bc his involvement with the changing situation in Ukraine, but a/o now see him staying ahead and LePen remaining @ no.2 in front of her rivals on the Right.
Update 4/8: Two days away from the election, she is at 23% in the polls, only 3% below Macron and 6% above any lower challenger. I think the chance that she will not be in the top 2 is <0.5%.
Recent polling has strengthened in her favour
I’m counting on a close second, and would prefer a distant third or fourth, but alas…
According to the financial times, gap being closed on macron by le pen.
Le Pen still tracking at the same rate of increase as Melenchon.   Likely number 2 with Macron.  This seems not to change at this point.
I'm glad this is "first or second" rather than just "second" - otherwise I would have to think about the odds that Macron might drop below her
with 6 days to go Le Pen is still solidly in second behind Macron - with polling showing 20% of the vote for her (Macron having 27% and her other closest challenger 15%)
Her lead is widening. Her place in the top 2 is looking almost assured.
Zemmour appeared to have stolen some of her support but she seems to have recovered recently and is clearly second in the polls.
The polls go Le Pen’s way. Now at 22%. It is almost certain she will place second
Eyeballing the Economist chart it looks like 80%.
Following the crowd and the polling, +10. https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/
Macron does not appear to be as strong as before and there is a good chance that Le Pen will certainly be in the top 2 and may even surprise the President.

https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220329-french-far-right-leader-le-pen-closing-gap-on-macron-polls -- Le Pen gaining ground...her closest competitors seem to be falling off a bit: https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/

Mélenchon could be a threat to Le Pen. He's rising in the polls very slightly faster than Le Pen. Still, no recent poll shows Mélenchon coming out ahead of Le Pen (I think - hard to tell who all the data points belong to). 
https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/

A repeat of 5 years ago is starting to look more likely.  There are a few people polling around the 10pc mark, but they have a way to catch up to LePen.  She has the benefit of being known at the moment.

Melenchon's rise would still have to  be high to overcome Le Pen.  Her recent rise has more or less matched his in absolute number (2% since the start of Ukraine invasion) so it will be difficult to catch him.  Using the POLITICO poll of Polls for numbers.

i'm still erring on the cautious side - her other potential rival (after Macron) has closed the gap by a % point - with 13 days left I don't know if he'll get closer, but he could close the gap more making it more competative
Le Pen will place 2nd, then lose in the run off.
Only 13 days left, and she's strongly ahead of all but Macron. Mélenchon seems to be the only possible challenger.
Zelenskyy shaming French - for supporting Russia economically - will push people away from right wing candidates making differences lesser

She has steadily been rising in the polls, although she is 5% above her closest opponent beneath her in the polls, whereas she was 6% above the closest opponent a couple weeks ago. Still, no recent poll has placed her beneath an opponent trending beneath her. With the elections coming in 14 days, it looks increasingly likely that she'll be number 2.
https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/
Moving up based on the Economist's election model.
This is only a battle for 2nd place. As of today, Le Pen clear 2nd.

Le Pen currently has 19% versus the next 13%. Macron far above. 
The war in Ukraine favors a candidate like Le Pen with a nationalistic and firm stance against aggressive dictators like Putin. 
I believe it is «almost» certain that she will place no. 2!

The rise of Authoritarian leaders has been on the rise across Europe but with varying degrees of success. Marine Le Pen was deafeated against Emanual Macron specifically because of the bigotry in her rhetoric. She Will place second.

Melenchon only the 2nd/3rd place competitor with any momentum at the moment but still looking like a pretty strong likelihood of a Le Pen Macron run off with Le Pen having very little hope of victory.
Most press see Le Pen as the main contender, so I would suggest this is high.
The odds of coming in first are very low, but there is a high probability of Le Pen coming in second.

I'm saying that Macron is pretty much a given due to his performance, role with Russia, EU chair (or what ever it is).
Le Pen is sitting pretty good in 2nd but there is competition. I am tempered down by other polls. 
However I think that war brings out Nationalistic tendencies and could lean on the far right. But will the pandemic grow the 'all in it together' left sentiment?
Can't say much more than that she's called the 'main rival’ in the article. Have to add the chance that she'll win and the chance that she'll be second.
Looks like Marine Le Pen will hold 2nd place.

Currently 7 individuals running in the election - Marcon (current PM) is consistently polling top (with lead of high single digits); Le Pen is consistently in 2nd in polls with ranges from 2%-6% - signal will be the campaigning of her closest competitor Melechon
Notwithstanding Melenchon's rise, Le Pen's baseline is higher
Mélenchon (La France Insoumise) is gaining in the polls, but Le Pen is still consistently 2nd.
Will place 2nd and end up losing the run off. Current president leads in the polls. Is popular, other parties are fractured and bad publicity.

base case 11 candidates. Pr(#1 or#2) = (1/11+1/10)*100% = 19% 
average gap poll and actual outcome = 3.9 percentage points with 10.2 percentage points in 2017 elections. https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/macron-won-but-the-french-polls-were-way-off/
current polls macron 30%, pen 17%, zemmour/melenchon/pecresse 12% https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/ gap between macron is above 10.2 percentage points. 
prob(macron proceeding second round) = 95% prob(pen proceeding second round and macron does) = 1/4 (1 out of pen/zemmour/melenchon/pecresse) =25%
or: 17/(17+12*3) = 32% 
prop(pen proceeding secound round and macron doesnt) = 1/4 + 1/3 
or: 17/53+17/31= 86.9% prop(pen proceeding secound round) = 0.95*0.32+0.05*86.9 = 34.7% chance round two le pen vs macron = 45% https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/how-we-forecast-the-french-election/21807484

Economist model giving her 70% . Sentiment will go against right wing due to Putin's aggressions, people vote for person that reflects themselves and even right wing supporters will pick more moderate canidates

The outside view in terms of a base rate is limited, in the 2017 election she placed second and Macron won. Polling suggests that's the current likely outcome as well. Based on the polling Le Pen has been close to a few challengers previously this winter, and exceeded Macron briefly last year. So I think it's likely she places second (or first) but uncertain. https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/
Very likely to reach this stage given she has always been polling at this level consistently and favoured of the candidates of her political stance

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_French_presidential_election
Le Pen polling steadily around 3-5% higher than the 3rd place candidate.
6 pts ahead of contender for run-off spot vs Macron as of today polls
The more right leaning candidates make Le Pen look moderate these days.  No one else can sustain a level over 15%.  Macron still in command but Le Pen second.

According to the Economist (for the sake of time I am only using this model for reference, however it supports my assumptions; confirmation bias I know) Le Penn has about a 2% chance of winning the presidency (https://www.economist.com/interactive/france-2022). However, everyone else has a 1% chance or less. There is less than a month left until elections and she seems to have a significant lead over the other candidates going into the second round.

The right is the only big opposition to Macron in polls right now. However, it's fragmentation (3 candidates) add some uncertainty to this event while also most likely eroding any chance of a first place even when considering the 2-stage voting system. Models, such as the one published by the Economist and other publications working mostly with historical probabilities and current polls, ascribe Le Pen more support than other right-wing contenders. Her relative moderation and especially, the weakness of Valerie Pecresse leaves her the highest likelihood to be the frontrunner from the political right. Thus I think this event is very likely.
Adjusting since support for Le Pen keeps slowly rising - as @camille2138 pointed out, it would take an unexpected event to reverse this trend.

3/17:  Clear odds on Macron placing first.  So the question is whether Le Pen or a competitor will take second place.  In the last month, support for Zemmour and Percresse has decreased; slight bump to Melenchon.  Support for Le Pen has been fairly stable.  While it is possible that one of the other candidates could beat Le Pen, unless something shifts significantly in the next weeks, I will leave this forecast as is. https://www.economist.com/interactive/france-2022

At the time of this forecast Macron is sitting at 30%, Le Pen at 18%, Melenchon at 12%, Zemmour 11%, Pecresse 11%, then a couple more below 6%. It appears looking at polls over time that Zemmour and Pecresse have faded pretty heavily post Russian Invasion. With most of there support seemingly going to Macron. These leave Le Pen pretty solidly in 2nd with significant gap afterwards, making it largely appear as a two horse race at this point. While I am leaving a 10% margin of error to cover cases where Melenchon is able to continue making gains or Zemmour/Pecresse are able to mount a comeback it seems very likely to come down to Macron vs Le Pen.
Le Pen building a meaningful gap between her and the other also-rans (Macron looks a shoe-in)

She seems to be holding steady with 17% in the polls and close competitors have fallen off. Given how close we are to the elction I find it difficult to see a severe misstep by Le Pen (or a rise of competition).

She still has the best chance of getting into the second round, which if she does, she’ll come second because it’s hard to see Macron losing at the moment. But there is quite a high chance of her not getting to the second round as both Pecresse and Zemmour are taking part of her vote.  While polls look like they are reverting to LePen support https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_French_presidential_election#Opinion_polls and both other candidates have problems (Zemmour = criminal charges, Pecresse = not good in big speeches and not impressing) There is a possibility of either of the others getting to the second round.  Small, but possible.  We live in strange times.

Will adapt probability down if poll gap gets below eg 2% or a multiway contest emerges. Currently looks pretty clear. It's also in 1st place candidate's interest that she should come second, and he or his team must (surely?) be subtly and deniably promoting that outcome (because  she is probably the most beatable second round adversary).

Le Pen has polled in first or second position for most polls over the past year [1]. She briefly dipped into third, behind Pecresse.  Macron has confirmed that he is running for re-election [2].  As stated in the Euronews article cited in the question, French election polls tend to be "notoriously unpredictable."  Still, there is less than one month before the election, which seems a short time for a lower polling candidate to make a move up.  Hence, Le Pen seems very likely to place second in the presidential election. [1] https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/
[2] https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/frances-macron-launches-bid-second-term-president-2022-03-03/

Outside view:
In all French Presidential elections since polling began, the candidate in second place at this stage would have resolved this question as "yes". Small sample size, so obviously not as useful Inside View:
Le Pen is also now trending upwards. I think it would take a pretty large polling error, or a scandal to resolve this as 'no'.

With his closest rival stating that she wants to “end of naturalization by marriage and of automatic citizenship for people born on French soil.”
I do believe that Macron has a better chance of wining, and Marine Le Pen will place second.
Also there’s an emerging “new personality Eric Zemmour”.

French politics appears to be very difficult to predict, especially on a question regarding an opposition party candidate who has already unsuccessfully challenged the incumbent.  Using this historical data of opposition candidates (very loosely) to form a base rate (outside view) we see high levels of variance (re: uncertainty) since the 60's.  Overlaying this with the various events shaping French politics internally and abroad (again, loosely) during these periods we can see Le Pen's appeal to appear in the final (i.e.  2nd) round (not necessarily winning) being more possible than not (but not by much) once more (and likely only once more if defeated again).
Zemmour has stolen some of her support but seems to have peaked out, so she remains second to Macron in the opinion polls.

Highly likely she will be on second place. She has a lot of experience in campaining (ran already two times for president) and the alternatives to her right seem an impossilbe choice even for right-leaning voters. Also, the Economist, whose prediction models have proven quite accurate recently, place her second.
Her closest rivals have been falling in the polls.

Based on the Economist forecast model.  The phrase "Unlikely outcomes happen more commonly than assumed." describing their model is odd.  I assume this is a not referring to their own assumptions and that their forecast reflects what they believe is the true probability. The model appears to be similar to how 538 forecasts in the US (though no electoral college with state by state forecasts to check calibration) using historic poll changes overtime to estimate the error of current polling.  Tough for me improve on their model and I am surprised others are so confident in doing so.

Opinion polling is very stable with her in second place, 5-8 points ahead of the 3rd place candidates.  But I don't know how reliable French opinion polling is, and whether Ukraine can shift any of the numbers around.
My instinct is to put higher chance on this, but leaving in some extra probability for unknown unknowns changing the outcome away from Le Pen getting second.
With the brief exception of two weeks in December of 2021, Le Pen has consistently polled in first or second place. https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/

Looking at the polling I think she's likely to place at least second. References:
https://www.economist.com/interactive/france-2022
https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/france/
Le Pen is certainly the candidate with higher chances to end up in second place. Mélenchon is going up slowly - probably too slowly.

Polls are close enough that if another candidate has a last minute surge like Melenchon did in 2017, Le Pen could lose. But she has proven she has staying power in the polls given she's been in 2nd the whole time, and she still has a solid lead at the moment.

Are we not reading this thoroughly? 
Le Pen is almost certain to place second. https://www.economist.com/interactive/france-2022
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_French_presidential_election
Current polling has her neck and neck with 3 or 4 other candidates- the current environment makes a radical right wing candidate less appealing but she has a strong base of support
I think she'll place as the 2nd- I think Emmanuel Makron will win.
She just can't.  With her campaign being financed by Putin and Orban she lost the remainder of her credibility.  She could only come in second if there weren't other candidates.
